questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with persistent tearing and discharge from the right eye since birth. Upon examination, there is no evidence of conjunctival injection, but a slight reflux of mucoid material is noted when pressure is applied over the lacrimal sac. The diagnosis of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (CNLDO) is made. Which of the following is NOT considered a common initial management approach for this condition?
questions.solution:
Congenital Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction (CNLDO):

  • CNLDO is a common pediatric condition caused by the failure of the nasolacrimal duct to open at birth, leading to persistent epiphora (excessive tearing) and discharge.
  • It typically results from a blockage at the valve of Hasner, the lower end of the nasolacrimal duct.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Parents often report persistent tearing (epiphora), recurrent discharge, and matting of the eyelashes, especially upon waking.
  • On physical examination, there may be mucous reflux when pressing over the lacrimal sac (positive "reflux on sac compression"), indicating retained fluid due to the blocked duct.
  • Importantly, there is no conjunctival injection, which helps differentiate CNLDO from conjunctivitis.

Management of CNLDO:

  • Observation:
    • CNLDO often resolves spontaneously in the first 6-12 months of life, and thus observation is a key part of management, especially in asymptomatic cases or those with minimal symptoms.
    • Spontaneous resolution occurs in up to 90% of cases by 1 year of age without the need for surgical intervention.
  • Digital massage (Crigler massage):
    • Digital massage over the lacrimal sac is a non-invasive technique used to increase pressure within the nasolacrimal duct, potentially helping to clear the obstruction.
    • It is often recommended as the first line of treatment, to be performed multiple times a day, particularly for mild cases.
  • Topical antibiotics:
    • Topical antibiotic drops (e.g., moxifloxacin) may be prescribed if there are signs of secondary bacterial infection, such as increased mucopurulent discharge or conjunctival irritation.
    • Antibiotics are not used to treat the obstruction itself but are useful in managing infections that may arise due to stagnant tears.
  • Probing:
    • Probing of the nasolacrimal duct is generally reserved for cases that do not resolve spontaneously by 12 months of age.
    • Probing is typically performed under general anesthesia and is considered safe and effective, with high success rates.
    • Performing probing earlier than 6-12 months is usually avoided unless there are complications or significant symptoms, which is why Option B (probing after 1 month of age) is incorrect.

Why Option B is Incorrect:

  • Probing before the age of 6 months is rarely necessary unless there are signs of infection or severe symptoms.
  • Standard practice involves a more conservative approach initially, with probing considered between 6-12 months only if conservative measures (massage, observation) fail.

Complications of Delayed Treatment:

  • Persistent obstruction can lead to recurrent dacryocystitis (infection of the lacrimal sac) and, in rare cases, orbital cellulitis, both of which require prompt medical attention.

Surgical Interventions:

  • In cases where probing fails or if there is a significant delay in presentation, more advanced surgical techniques such as balloon dacryoplasty or silicone tube intubation may be considered.

Tags:

  • Congenital NLDO
  • FMGE july 2021
  • Occuloplasty

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption presents with gradual, painless bilateral vision loss. Visual field testing shows central scotomas, and there is a reduction in color vision. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
A)Tobacco and Alcohol:

  • Gradual, painless bilateral vision loss, central scotomas, and loss of color vision are typical of toxic optic neuropathy.
  • The patient's history of chronic alcohol consumption and the gradual onset of symptoms strongly point towards nutritional deficiencies and toxic effects of tobacco and alcohol.
  • Chronic use of both tobacco and alcohol is a well-known cause of toxic optic neuropathy.
  • Nutritional deficiencies, especially of vitamin B12 and folate, are associated with chronic alcohol use, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction in the optic nerve.

Fundoscopic Findings:

  • In early stages, the optic disc may appear normal, but as the condition progresses, optic nerve pallor (especially temporal) can be observed.

Management:

  • Immediate cessation of alcohol and tobacco use is essential.
  • Nutritional supplementation with B-complex vitamins, especially vitamin B12, folate, and thiamine, is necessary for treatment and recovery.
  • Early intervention can prevent further deterioration, though some vision loss may be permanent if the condition is advanced.

Other options:

A) Methanol: Causes rapid vision loss, metabolic acidosis, and severe systemic symptoms like abdominal pain and confusion. It is more acute and severe compared to tobacco-alcohol-related neuropathy.

B) Ethambutol: Known to cause optic neuropathy, but this typically occurs in patients on long-term treatment for tuberculosis.

D) Chloramphenicol: Rarely causes optic neuropathy. It is more associated with systemic toxicities like bone marrow suppression.

Stimulation of ATP sensitive K+ channels
Inhibition of ligand gated calcium channels

questions.text: In response to hypoxia in systemic arteries there is vasodilatation. Which of the following channels primarily are responsible for vasodilation?
questions.solution:
• Option B - ATP-sensitive potassium channels are crucial in the vasodilatory response to hypoxia.
    When oxygen levels are low, the decrease in ATP production leads to the opening of these channels. The opening of K+ATP channels allows potassium to efflux, causing hyper-polarization of the smooth muscle cell membrane. This hyper-polarization reduces the activity of voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to a decrease in intracellular calcium levels, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
  • Option A - O2-sensitive potassium channels are found in certain tissues like the carotid body, where they play a role in sensing oxygen levels.
    In hypoxic conditions, This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ influx, primarily via L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels..It causes vasoconstriciton in pulmonary vessels.
  • Option C - Ligand-gated calcium channels are typically involved in responses triggered by specific ligands (such as neurotransmitters) binding to their receptors. It may cause vasodilatation but the primary mechanism is K+ channels.
  • Option- D - The Na+ K+ ATPase pump is crucial for maintaining the electrochemical gradient across cell membranes by pumping sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell using ATP.

choices.text: Lenticular Rupture Cataract with immediate phacoemulsification.
Rosette Cataract with protective shield and anti-inflammatory therapy.
Foreign Body Cataract with urgent foreign body removal and lens extraction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presents with a cataract following a metallic object injury to his eye. On examination, you observe a "snowflake" pattern of opacification in the lens. What type of traumatic cataract is this most likely, and what is the recommended initial management approach?
questions.solution:
B) Rosa-Bonn(Rosette) Cataract: Characteristic of blunt trauma; initial management includes protective measures and anti-inflammatory treatment

other options clarified:

A) Lenticular Rupture Cataract: This type is associated with penetrating trauma and would require urgent removal of foreign bodies.

C) Foreign Body Cataract: Requires urgent intervention to remove foreign bodies and may not apply to the "snowflake" pattern seen here.

D) Morgagnian Cataract: Typically associated with advanced blunt trauma; YAG laser capsulotomy is not the initial treatment for traumatic cataracts.

Types of Traumatic Cataracts

Blunt Trauma Cataract:

  • Rosette Cataract:
    • Appearance: Characterized by punctate opacifications or "snowflake" opacities in the lens.
  • Morgagnian Cataract:
    • Appearance: Advanced stage where the lens cortex liquefies, leaving only the nucleus.

Penetrating Trauma Cataract:

  • Lenticular Rupture Cataract:
    • Appearance: Rupture of the lens capsule with leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber.
  • Foreign Body Cataract:
    • Appearance: Localized opacifications or total opacification of the lens due to retained foreign bodies.

Management of Traumatic Cataracts

Immediate Management:

  • Protection and Stabilization:
    • Protective Shield: Apply to prevent further damage.
    • Anti-inflammatory Therapy: Topical steroids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to control inflammation.
    • Antibiotic Therapy: To prevent or manage infection.
  • Assessment and Stabilization:
    • Ocular Examination: Thorough evaluation to determine the extent of damage and associated injuries.
    • Management of Associated Injuries: Address any corneal, retinal, or other ocular injuries as needed.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Timing:
    • Blunt Trauma: Surgery is typically deferred until inflammation subsides and the eye has stabilized.
    • Penetrating Trauma: Urgent intervention may be required to remove foreign bodies and repair the lens capsule.
  • Surgical Techniques:
    • Phacoemulsification: Preferred for less complicated cases where the cataract can be removed using ultrasonic energy.
    • Manual Extraction: May be necessary for more severe cases with significant damage or foreign bodies.

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of ligand gated channel?
questions.solution:
• Option A - The Ryanodine receptor (RyR) is an example of a ligand-gated channel. It is primarily found in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells, where it plays a crucial role in calcium release during muscle contraction.
    • The RyR is activated by calcium induced calcium release (CICR) allowing calcium ions to flow out of the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm.
  • Option B - The Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is a voltage-gated calcium channel located in the T-tubules of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells.
  • Option c - Pressure receptor channels, such as those involved in mechano-transduction, are typically mechanosensitive channels.
    • These channels open in response to mechanical forces such as pressure, stretch, or deformation of the cell membrane.

questions.text: Identify the splint and choose correct option according to its indication:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Bohler-Brown splint.

Skeletal traction is used for fracture shaft of femur and intertrochanteric fractures.

Bohler-Braun splint: It has a number of pulleys (1-3) over which the traction cord passes while giving skeletal traction for different fractures. It is more convenient than Thomas splint since it has no ring. The ring of a Thomas splint is a common cause of discomfort, especially in elderly people. A Bohler-Braun splint has no inbuilt system of countertraction, hence it is not suitable for transportation.

Option A: It is one of the commonest splints used in orthopaedic practice. It was devised by H.O. Thomas, initially for immobilisation for tuberculosis of the knee. It is now commonly used for the immobilisation and transportation of hip and thigh injuries.

Fig. Thomas splint

Option D: Cramer-wire splint: This splint is used for temporary splintage of fractures during transportation. It is made up of two thick parallel wires with interlacing wires. It can be bent into different shapes in order to immobilise different parts of the body.

Fig. Cramer splint

questions.text: A 48 year old man was brought to the emergency department with an acute myocardial infarction (MI). The man regularly used sildenafil in preparation for sexual intercourse because of an erectile dysfunction. He had recently been diagnosed with exertional angina, and he had been taking an appropriate prescribed therapy. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
• Sildenafil is used in erectile dysfunction because it inhibits isoform 5 of phosphodiesterase, which is found in high concentration in smooth muscle cells of the corpora cavernosa.
  • This increases the concentration of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which in turn stimulates the dephosphorylation of the myosin light chain.
  • Because of this mechanism of action, sildenafil potentiates the action of nitrates (which also cause an increase in cGMP), and severe hypotension and a few myocardial infarctions have been reported in men using both drugs.

Sildenafil

Sildenafil acts by selectively inhibiting PDE-5 and enhancing NO action in corpus cavernosum.

Adverse effects

  • Side effects are mainly due to PDE-5 inhibition related vasodilatation-
  • Headache,
  • Nasal congestion,
  • Dizziness,
  • Facial flushing and fall in BP,
  • Loose motions.

Sildenafil markedly potentiates the vasodilator action of nitrates; precipitous fall in BP; MI can occur.

Sildenafil is contraindicated in patients of coronary heart disease and those taking nitrates.

Different nitrates

  • Glyceryl Trinitrate / Nitroglycerine [GTN/ NTG]
  • Isosorbide Dinitrate [IDN]
  • Isosorbide Mononitrate [IMN]
  • Penta Erythrital Tetra Nitrate [PETN]
  • Amyl Nitrite [AN]
  • Nitrates should not be given with Sildenafil

[Risk of Severe hypotension]

Adverse effects These are mostly due to vasodilatation.

Mnemonic [MRF]

Methemoglobinemia

Rashes are rare (common with pentaerythritol tetranitrate)

Fullness in head, throbbing headache;

Flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting; these are due to postural hypotension

Option B: Nitroprusside can cause an increase in cGMP, and it’s actions are potentiated by sildenafil, but the drug is not used to treat angina.

Option A & D: None of these drugs have actions potentiated by sildenafil.

Tags:

  • Sildenafil
  • Must Know

questions.text:
A renal allograft biopsy shows:
Fibrosis and sclerosis of the glomeruli
duplication of the tubular basement membrane
Interstitial fibrosis and inflammation
peritubular capillaritis
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of fibrosis and sclerosis in the glomeruli, tubular basement membrane duplication, peritubular capillaritis, and interstitial fibrosis and inflammation is characteristic of chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN).

  • CAN is a long-term complication of kidney transplantation, resulting from chronic immune-mediated damage and non-immune factors.
  1. Acute cellular rejection is characterized by tubulitis, interstitial inflammation, and vascular rejection.
  2. Acute antibody-mediated rejection is characterized by the presence of donor-specific antibodies and C4d deposition in the graft.
  3. Recurrent glomerulonephritis would show characteristic histological features of the original disease, such as membranous nephropathy or IgA nephropathy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The combination of fibrosis and sclerosis in the glomeruli, tubular basement membrane duplication, peritubular capillaritis, and interstitial fibrosis and inflammation is characteristic of chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN).

questions.text:
Choose the option with the correct statement about inter-vertebral discs (IVD):
1. Nucleus pulposus is derived from ectoderm
2. Annulus fibrosus is derived from mesoderm
3. Nutrition of IVD is derived through diffusion through CSF
4. IVD allows spinal motion and stability.
questions.solution:
Intervertebral Discs (IVDs)

  • Functions:
    • Allow spinal motion and stability. (Option 4)
    • Act as cushioning for axial loads on the spine.
  • Components:
    1. Central Nucleus Pulposus:
      • Derived from the notochord. (Option 1)
      • Hydrated gel with compressibility.
      • Low collagen (type II) and high proteoglycan (and glycosaminoglycan) content.
      • Proteoglycans make up a higher percentage of dry weight.
      • With time, undergoes loss of proteoglycans and water (desiccation).
    2. Surrounding Annulus Fibrosis:
      • Derived from mesoderm. (Option 2)
      • Provides extensibility and increased tensile strength.
      • High collagen (type I) and low proteoglycan content.
      • Proteoglycans make up a lower percentage of dry weight.
      • Superficial layer contains nerve fibers.
  • Composition:
    • Water: 85%
    • Proteoglycans
    • Type II Collagen: 20% of dry weight in the nucleus pulposus.
    • Type I Collagen: 60% of dry weight in the annulus fibrosis.
  • Neurovascularity:
    • Dorsal Root Ganglion: Gives rise to the sinuvertebral nerve, innervating the superficial fibers of the annulus.
    • Avascular: Nutrients and fluid diffuse from the vertebral end plates. Diffusion is impaired by calcification with aging. (Option 3)
  • Aging Disc:
    • Early Degenerative Disc Disease:
      • An irreversible process.
      • IL-1β stimulates the release of MMPs, nitric oxide, IL-6, and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2).
    • Changes:
      • Decreased water content and conversion to fibrocartilage.
      • Decreased hydrostatic pressure due to fewer large proteoglycans (aggrecan).
      • Fibronectin cleavage or fragmentation is associated with degeneration.
      • Increase in keratan sulfate concentration and decrease in chondroitin sulfate.
      • Increase in relative collagen concentration, with no change in absolute quantity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) presents with abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and a rapid weight gain of 5 kg over the past three days. Ultrasound shows enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts and ascites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OHSS IS most severe complication of assisted reproductive techniques

  • It is characterized by ovarian enlargement, ascites, and rapid weight gain, typically occurring after ovulation induction or IVF
  • It occurs due to fluid shift from the intravascular space to the third space,causing ascites,pleural effusion, and even thromboembolic events in severe cases.
  • Most important trigger for OHSS is Injection HCG
  • Most important mediator is VEGF

questions.text: A 6 month old child was brought to paediatrician with weakness in his left upper limb since birth. The baby was born at full term by assisted vaginal delivery using forceps. On examination doctor noticed that his left arm was adducted and medially rotated and forearm was extended and pronated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erb's paralysis: It is due to injury to upper trunk of brachial plexus due to undue separation of head from shoulder during birth.

Deformity (Position of hand):

  • Arm : Hangs by the side, adducted and medially rotated.
  • Forearm : Extended and pronated

Disability: The following movements lost:

  • Abduction of lateral rotation of arm
  • Flexion and supination of forearm
  • Biceps and supinator jerks are lost
  • Sensation are lost over a small area over lower part of deltoid.

Option wise explanation:

Option A: Klumpke's paralysis: It is due to injury to lower trunk of brachial plexus. It will cause paralysis of intrinsic muscle of hand lead to claw hand deformity.

Option C: Dupuytren's contracture: It is due to fibrosis of media part of palmar aponeurosis that leads to proximal and middle phalanges are flexed while distal phalanges remain extended.

Option D: Axillary nerve damage: Axillary nerve may be damaged in fracture of surgical neck of femur that lead to paralysis of deltoid muscle. This will cause inability to abduct the upper limb.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a sudden loss of vision in the right eye over the past week, accompanied by pain on eye movement. On examination, she has reduced visual acuity in the right eye and a central scotoma. MRI of the brain and orbits is ordered. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which initial treatment is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Optic neuritis

Inflammation of the optic nerve that often leads to a sudden loss of vision and can be associated with various systemic conditions. It can affect one or both eyes and is commonly seen in multiple sclerosis (MS).

Causes:

  • Multiple Sclerosis (MS): The most common cause in young adults.
  • Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO): An autoimmune condition affecting the optic nerve and spinal cord.
  • Infections: Viral (e.g., herpes simplex), bacterial (e.g., syphilis), or parasitic infections.
  • Autoimmune Diseases: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), sarcoidosis.
  • Optic Nerve Compression: Tumors, especially in the case of secondary optic neuritis.
  • Drug Reactions: Certain medications, though less common.

Clinical Features:

  • Visual Symptoms:
    • Sudden onset of unilateral (or sometimes bilateral) vision loss.
    • Often associated with pain, especially with eye movement.
    • Loss of color vision (dyschromatopsia), particularly red color.
  • Fundoscopic Examination:
    • Normal in Early Stages: The optic disc may appear normal in the initial phase.
    • Optic Disc Swelling: In some cases, disc swelling may be present.
    • Retrobulbar Neuritis: May present with normal fundoscopic findings if inflammation occurs behind the eye.
  • Visual Field Testing: Central scotoma or altitudinal field defects are common.

Diagnosis:

Clinical Evaluation:

  • History and Symptoms: Detailed history of vision loss, pain with eye movement, and any associated symptoms like neurological deficits.
  • Neurological Examination: To assess for any systemic neurological conditions, such as MS.

Imaging:

  • MRI of the Brain and Orbits: Identifies lesions characteristic of MS, evaluates for optic nerve involvement, and rules out other causes of optic nerve damage.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Can assess retinal nerve fiber layer thickness and optic nerve head appearance.

Management:

Acute Treatment:

  • Corticosteroids: High-dose intravenous corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are commonly used to reduce inflammation and speed up recovery.
  • Supportive Care: Pain management and symptomatic treatment.

Long-Term Management:

  • Multiple Sclerosis: If associated with MS, disease-modifying therapies (e.g., interferons, glatiramer acetate) may be indicated.
  • Regular Follow-up: Monitoring of visual recovery and assessment for any long-term complications.

Discussing other options:

  • B) Retinal Detachment: Typically presents with visual field changes and does not usually cause pain with eye movement.
  • C) Diabetic Retinopathy: Involves retinal changes due to diabetes, not associated with sudden onset of vision loss and pain.
  • D) Age-related Macular Degeneration: Affects central vision but is not associated with pain on eye movement.

questions.text: Which among the following is the interstitial oedematous subtype of acute pancreatitis for > 4 weeks according to the revised morphological features of acute pancreatitis?
The cutaneous innervation of marked area is
questions.solution:
The marked area is 1st interdigital cleft.

Common peroneal nerve : It is a terminal branch of sciatic nerve in the popliteal fossa and passes through the lateral side of the neck of fibula and then divides into deep and superficial peroneal nerve. It is mostly damaged at the neck of fibula.

  • Deep peroneal nerve supply muscles of anterior compartment and skin of 1st web space and
  • superficial peroneal nerve supply muscles of lateral compartment of leg and skin of lateral side of leg and dorsum of foot.

Option wise explanation:

Option A : Superficial peroneal nerve : supply greater part of dorsum of foot except territories supplied by saphenous nerve, Sural nerve and deep peroneal nerve.

Option B : Saphenous nerve : supply medial side of leg and medial margin of dorsum of foot.

Option C : Deep peroneal nerve : supply the 1st interdigital cleft area.

Option D : Sural nerve : supply lateral border of foot.

questions.text: What is the most effective method for preventing Japanese encephalitis?
questions.solution:
The most effective method for preventing Japanese encephalitis is Mosquito control measures as Culex mosquito is vector for Japanese encephalitis.

Vector: Culex mosquitoes

Reservoir: Water birds

Amplifier: Pigs

Dead end host: Horses and humans

choices.text: External intercostal muscle and internal intercostal muscle

questions.text: The neurovascular bundle in thoracic wall is between
questions.solution:
Intercostal space:

The space between the two adjacent ribs are known as intercostal spaces.

The neurovascular bundle is lies between internalintercostal and Intercostalisintimi.

Thus there are 11 intercostal spaces on either side.

Each space contains the following structure:

  • Three intercostal muscles
  • Intercostal nerves
  • Intercostal arteries
  • Intercostal veins
  • Intercostal lymph vessels and lymph nodes

The neurovascular bundle consisting of intercostal nerve and vessels lies between internal intercostal and Intercostalisintimi.

The neurovascular bundle are arranged in the following order from above downwards : (Mnemonics : VAN)

  • Intercostal Vein
  • Intercostal Artery
  • Intercostal Nerve

Intercostal space present between internal intercostal and intercostalisintimi (innermost intercostal)

Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and D : are incorrect for location of neurovascular bundle in thoracic wall.

Option C : The neurovascular bundle is lies between internal intercostal and Intercostalisintimi.

Reference: Human Anatomy, B D Chaurasia, Volume 1, 9th edition, Page No 248.

questions.text: As compared to a routine case control study, nested case control study avoids problems (in study design) related to:
questions.solution:
In routine case control study, temporality can not be established that is we are not able to know when exposure started that is before or after the disease.

In nested case control study, temporality can be established because in this study started by exposure.

Nested case control study uses over Routine case control study are:

  • Temporality established
  • Easy to do
  • Economical

questions.text: All are ventral hernias except:
questions.solution:
Inguinal hernia and femoral hernia are part of groin hernias and not ventral hernia

  • Ventral hernias
    • Umbilical-paraumbilical
    • Epigastric
    • Incisional
    • Parastomal
    • Spigelian
    • Lumbar
    • Traumatic
  • This term refers to hernias of the anterior abdominal wall. Inguinal and femoral hernias are not included even though they are ventral.
  • Lumbar hernia is included despite being dorsolateral. The European Hernia Society classification (2009) distinguished primary ventral from incisional hernia but did not include parastomal hernia. We have included parastomal hernia and traumatic hernia.

questions.text: Which artery is the main blood supply of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
• The small intestine has a very rich blood supply, derived from the superior mesenteric artery, while venous drainage is via the portal venous system, into which the superior mesenteric vein drains blood rich in nutrients after a meal.
  • This arrangement facilitates processing of the nutrients by the liver, into which the portal vein drains in turn.
  • The lymphatic drainage of the small intestine follows the arterial supply.

questions.text: 'En masse' removal of organs in autopsy is which technique?
questions.solution:
Evisceration Methods (Techniques of autopsy) :

  1. Letulle's technique:
    • Described by Letulle.
    • Also known as, 'En masse' or 'En bloc' dissection
      En masse = In a group; all together
      En bloc = All together or all at the same time
    • In this technique, oral, cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one large organ block.
    • Leaves all attachments intact.
    • Commonly done in medical colleges to teach students
  2. Virchow's Method:
    • Organ by organ removal
    • Individual organ removal one by one.
    • Subsequent dissection of isolated organs.
    • Useful for assessing individual organ pathology.
    • Quick and effective for single organ focus.
    • Most common method in India
  3. Gohn's technique:
    • Developed by Ghon.
    • Also known as, 'Block by block' dissection
    • Cervical & thoracic organs, abdominal organs and the urogenital system are removed as separate organ blocks.
  4. In Situ Dissection:
    • Developed by Rokitansky.
    • Also known as In-situ dissection
    • Organs dissected in situ with minimal evisceration.
    • Rarely performed.
    • Done in infected & suspected infection cases.

Alcohol Consumption increases Glucose Production leading to Hyperglycemia

questions.text: Consumption of Moderate amount of alcohol immediately after 03 hours of continuous aerobic exercise in healthy male subject is not advisable. Which important metabolic reaction is involved for adverse effect in this condition.
questions.solution:
• Alcohol Metabolism by Alcohol Dehydrogenase enzyme involves transfer of Electrons to Oxidized NAD resulting in increase in Ratio of NADH to NAD which favours reduction of Pyruvate to lactate and Oxaloacetate to malate.
  • After heavy continuous exercise depletes glycogen store in liver. In this condition NADH to NAD ratio will divert gluconeogenic Precuresor Pyruvate and Oxaloacetate into alternate pathway. It will lead to Hypoglycemia.

Ethanol metabolism ↑ NADH/ NAD+ ratio in liver, causing:

  • Lactic acidosis- ↑ pyruvate conversion to lactate
  • Fasting hypoglycemia- ↓ gluconeogenesis due to ↑ conversion of OAA to malate
  • Ketoacidosis-diversion of acetyl-CoA into ketogenesis rather than TCA cycle
  • Hepatosteatosis- ↑ conversion of DHAP to glycerol-3-P
    • 4A ; acetyl-CoA diverges into fatty acid synthesis
    • 4B , which combines with glycerol-3-P to synthesize triglycerides
  • Option a - there in ↑ NADH\NAD+ , so high amount of NADH generation
  • Option c - NADH\NAD ratio is increased and not decreased
  • Option d - alcohol consumption leads to hypoglycaemia as metabolism is diverted to ketogenesis so no gluconeogenesis

questions.text: A 30 years old male visited hospital with complaint of pain, numbness and tingling in his left forearm and hand when he raises it above his head. On examination doctor found his left hand colder and pallor compared to right hand when arm was abducted and external rotated. He has no history of trauma. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Thoracic outlet syndrome : It is characterized by compression of neurovascular structure as they pass through thoracic outlet It is presents with pain, numbness , tingling and diminished pulse with arm movements

Option wise explanation:

Option A: Carpal tunnel syndrome : It is compression of median nerve at the wrist causing numbness and tingling on the thumb, index and middle finger.

Option B: Cervical Radiculopathy : It involve nerve root compression at cervical spine but not with present with a diminished pulse or cold extremity.

Option C: Rotator cuff injury : It cause shoulder pain and weakness but not neurovascular symptoms like numbness or diminished pulse.

choices.text: Surveillance of non-communicable diseases and their risk factor
Surveillance of communicable diseases and their risk factors
Surveillance of socioeconomic status in the community
Assessing rate of mortality of non-communicable diseases

questions.text: STEPS is the WHO recommended tool for
questions.solution:
A) Surveillance of non-communicable diseases and their risk factors

  • The STEPS tool is a standardized method recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for monitoring non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, chronic respiratory diseases, and cancer, along with their risk factors (e.g., smoking, physical inactivity, unhealthy diet, alcohol consumption).
  • It provides countries with a framework for collecting, analyzing, and disseminating data to monitor trends over time and guide public health policies.
  • It has three steps:
    • Step 1: Questionnaire
      • Gather data on behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, and physical activity.
    • Step 2: Physical Measurements
      • Collects physical data such as height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure.
    • Step 3: Biochemical Measurements
      • Measures biomarkers like blood glucose and cholesterol through blood and urine samples to assess clinical risk factors for NCDs.

B) Surveillance of communicable diseases and their risk factors

  • Communicable diseases refer to infections that can spread from one person to another, such as influenza, tuberculosis, or HIV. Surveillance systems for communicable diseases focus on tracking outbreaks, spread, and control measures.
  • The STEPS tool is not designed for communicable diseases; other surveillance methods like Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response (IDSR) are used for these.

C) Surveillance of socioeconomic status in the community

  • Socioeconomic status (SES) surveillance involves tracking income, education, employment, and other social determinants of health in a population. This data helps assess the overall well-being of a community and the impact of SES on health.
  • The STEPS tool is not specifically designed to measure socioeconomic status, although some SES-related factors may indirectly be assessed as part of risk factor data collection.

D) Assessing rate of mortality of non-communicable diseases

  • Mortality rate refers to the frequency of death in a population. While the STEPS tool does gather data on risk factors for NCDs, it is not directly used to calculate mortality rates. Other tools and surveys, such as civil registration and vital statistics systems, are used for mortality data.

questions.text: A 36 year-old woman presents with amenorrhea for 6 months. Her serum FSH is elevated, and estrogen levels are low. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Premature Ovarian Insufficiency (POI), also known as premature menopause, occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before the age of 40. In POI, serum FSH is elevated, indicating the body's attempt to stimulate the ovaries, while estrogen levels are low due to ovarian failure. This combination is typical of POI, and the patient presents with amenorrhea as a result of this hormonal imbalance.

Option Explanations:

  • A) Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS): In PCOS, there is usually normal or low FSH, and estrogen levels are typically normal or elevated due to anovulation. Elevated FSH and low estrogen are not characteristic of PCOS.
  • C) Hypothalamic Amenorrhea: In hypothalamic amenorrhea, there is a deficiency in the signaling from the hypothalamus to the pituitary, leading to low FSH and low estrogen. Elevated FSH is not typical of hypothalamic amenorrhea.
  • D) Asherman's Syndrome: Caused by intrauterine adhesions, it leads to amenorrhea but would not typically result in elevated FSH or low estrogen levels. Hormone levels are usually normal.

questions.text: What is the odour of the mummified body?
questions.solution:
The mummified body is odourless.

  • The absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air is necessary for the process of mummification.
  • Mummification is a process of dehydration or drying and shrivelling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

During the process of mummification, the body becomes progressively dehydrated and the normal putrefactive decomposition is inhibited. It occurs most readily in a current of dry warm air. Although dryness is clearly necessary, exactly how warm the atmosphere needs to be is less certain.

questions.text: All of the following arteries form circle of Willis except
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis ( Circulus Arteriosus) : It is six sided polygonal of arteries formed at base of brain by branches of basilar and internal carotid arteries.

It is formed around the interpeduncular fossa and lies in the interpeduncular cistern.

Formation of circle of Willis :

  • Anteriorly : by anterior cerebral and anterior communicating arteries
  • Posteriorly : by the basilar artery dividing into two posterior cerebral arteries
  • Laterally on each side : by posterior communicating artery connecting internal carotid artery with the posterior cerebral artery.

Option wise explanation :

Option A, C and D : arteries form circle of Willis.

Option B : Middle cerebral artery : does not form circle of Willis

questions.text: 38-week pregnant woman delivers a baby with the head out, but the shoulders are stuck. Which maneuver is the first step in managing shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency that occurs when the baby's shoulders get stuck behind the mother's pubic bone after the head is delivered. The first and most effective step in managing shoulder dystocia is the McRoberts maneuver, which involves hyperflexing the mother's legs tightly against her abdomen. This helps to rotate the pelvis, flatten the sacrum, and widen the pelvic outlet, facilitating the delivery of the baby's shoulders.

Option Explanations:

  • B) Fundal pressure: This is contraindicated in shoulder dystocia because it can worsen the impaction by pushing the shoulder further into the pubic bone.
  • C) Zavanelli maneuver: A last-resort maneuver where the baby's head is reinserted into the vagina to allow for a cesarean section. It is not the first step.
  • D) Symphysiotomy: This involves surgically cutting the pubic symphysis to widen the pelvis and is rarely used. It is considered only in extreme cases where other maneuvers have failed.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is glove and stocking hypostasis most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
• Glove and stocking hypostasis means postmortem staining of at thighs, legs, feet, forearm and hands.
  • This occurs in the vertical suspension of the body as in hanging where these parts form the dependent parts.
  • Sites of postmortem hypostasis depending on the position of the body:
    • Supine: Back except on pressure areas such as scapular region, buttocks, and calves (contact pallor, contact blanching, areas of contact flattening)
    • Vertical as in hanging: Legs, feet, forearm, and hands (glove and stocking type of hypostasis)
    • Drowning: Face, the upper part of the chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and the calves as they are the dependant parts

GLOVE AND STOCKING HYPOSTASIS

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a previous cesarean section presents at 40 weeks with severe abdominal pain, loss of fetal station, and maternal tachycardia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Uterine rupture is a serious obstetric emergency that typically occurs in women with a history of a previous cesarean section or other uterine surgery. The key signs and symptoms include:

  • Severe abdominal pain: Often sudden and intense.
  • Loss of fetal station: This occurs when the baby moves back up into the abdomen after being engaged in the pelvis, which is a hallmark of uterine rupture.
  • Maternal tachycardia: Can occur due to pain, blood loss, or shock.
  • Fetal heart rate- Tachycardia followed by bradycardia
  • Hamaturia, bleeding per vagina

The combination of these signs, particularly in a woman with a history of a previous cesarean section, makes uterine rupture the most likely diagnosis.

Option Explanations:

  • A) Placental abruption: Involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, typically causing vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain, but not loss of fetal station or the specific presentation of uterine rupture.
  • C) Amniotic fluid embolism: A rare but serious condition that presents with sudden cardiovascular collapse and respiratory distress, not with abdominal pain or loss of fetal station.
  • D) Vasovagal syncope: Causes fainting and is typically related to a sudden drop in blood pressure, not severe abdominal pain or loss of fetal station.

questions.text: Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) shows which type of epidemic?
questions.solution:
Source is one but giving exposure to multiple people. Example: Public well contaminated with cholera bacilli.

Option wise explanation:

Option (A): Point source - Common source but one time exposure. Example: Food poisoning

Option (C): Propagative type - From person to person. Example: Measles, Chicken pox

Option (D): Secular trend - Slow long term fluctuation Example: Non communicable disease

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 36 weeks gestation presents with painless fresh vaginal bleeding immediately after rupture of membranes. The fetal heart rate is 80 bpm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vasa previa occurs when fetal blood vessels, unsupported by placental or umbilical tissue, run across or near the internal os of the cervix. When the membranes rupture, these vessels can tear, leading to painless vaginal bleeding and fetal blood loss, which results in fetal bradycardia (fetal heart rate of 80 bpm in this case). The key features of this case are the painless fresh vaginal bleeding after rupture of membranes and the low fetal heart rate, which strongly suggest vasa previa.

Option Explanations:

  • A) Placenta previa: Involves the placenta covering the cervical os and causes painless vaginal bleeding, but it typically occurs before the rupture of membranes, and fetal bradycardia is not a typical initial finding.
  • C) Placental abruption: Typically presents with painful vaginal bleeding due to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall. The bleeding is usually maternal, not fetal, and would likely be accompanied by abdominal pain.
  • D) Uterine rupture: Usually presents with severe abdominal pain, loss of fetal station, and abnormal fetal heart rate, but not typically painless bleeding right after membrane rupture.

questions.text: The following is victim of firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.solution: The image shows a wound of entry surrounded by tattooing(peppering). There is no blackening(smudging). That means the target was beyond the reach of the smoke/soot but within the range of powder particles, i.e., intermediate range.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetic agent is contraindicated in hypertensive patients posted for general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is contraindicated in hypertensive patients because it increases blood pressure.

Propofol : Contraindicated only in shock.

Thiopentone : Contraindicated in shock, porphyria and bronchial asthma.

Ketamine: Contraindicated in cardiac patients, CAD, hypertension, neurosurgery, epilepsy and chronic illnesses.

questions.text: A young male who is a user of black tar heroin presents to the emergency room with descending paralysis, double vision and respiratory failure for which he is subsequently intubated and mechanically ventilated. He has bilaterally dilated pupils and absent deep tendon reflexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Black tar heroin is contaminated with by-products of the manufacturing process, adulterants, and diluents and therefore is considered the most probable source of C. botulinum spores. Botulism can cause bilateral cranial nerve palsies that may be followed by symmetric, descending flaccid paralysis that may cause respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents with severe itching, especially on her palms and soles, without a rash. Her liver function tests show elevated bile acids. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
The woman in this case likely has intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP), a liver disorder unique to pregnancy that causes a buildup of bile acids in the bloodstream, leading to severe itching (particularly on the palms and soles), and it can increase the risk of fetal complications.The best marker of ICP is serum bile acids.

Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment for ICP (Intrahepatic Cholestasis of pregnancy) as it helps reduce serum bile acid levels,improves liver function,and alleviates itching.

C) Ursodeoxycholic acid and delivery at 36-37 weeks (correct answer)

  • Usage: Ursodeoxycholic acid is a medication that helps reduce bile acids in the blood and relieve itching in ICP. It is the standard treatment for ICP and improves liver function.
  • Delivery timing: Delivery is typically recommended at 36-37 weeks in women with ICP because the condition increases the risk of stillbirth, especially as pregnancy progresses beyond 37 weeks.
  • This is the best option, as it addresses both the maternal symptoms and reduces fetal risks. Ursodeoxycholic acid helps manage the condition, and timed delivery helps prevent complications for the baby.

Explanation of other options:

A) Topical corticosteroids

  • Usage: These are generally used for skin conditions like rashes or eczema to reduce inflammation.
  • Since the itching in ICP is due to elevated bile acids rather than a skin inflammation or rash, topical corticosteroids would not address the underlying problem. Therefore, this is not an appropriate treatment for ICP.

B) Antihistamines

  • Usage: Antihistamines are typically used for allergic reactions to relieve itching by blocking histamine release.
  • In ICP, the itching is not due to histamine release but bile acid buildup. While antihistamines might provide minor relief from itching, they do not address the root cause and are not effective in preventing complications related to ICP. Hence, this is not the best management.

D) Immediate delivery

  • Usage: Immediate delivery may be necessary in certain obstetric emergencies, such as preeclampsia or fetal distress.
  • In ICP, immediate delivery is not typically necessary unless there are signs of fetal compromise. Delivery is usually planned for around 36-37 weeks to minimize the risk of stillbirth, but delivering immediately at 34 weeks without signs of fetal distress would expose the baby to risks of prematurity without sufficient benefit. Therefore, this is not the best option unless the situation is critical.

questions.text: When there is a break in the chain of transmission, so that no new case develops but agent persists is called as?
Interval between Primary case and secondary case is known as
questions.solution:
Primary case: First case

Secondary case: Develop after primary case

Serial interval is time gap between primary and secondary case.

Other options explanation:

Option (A): Median incubation time: Time taken for 50% cases to develop.

Option (B): Generation time: Time taken from receive of infection to maximum infectivity.

Option (D): Secondary attack rate: From primary case how many people got disease. This is telling about communicability or infectivity of disease.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates the direction of an abrasion caused by tangential force?
questions.solution:
In an abrasion caused by a tangential force, the direction of the force is determined by epidermal tags.

  • Grazes, aka, sliding, scraping or grinding abrasion (As seen in the image) occur when there is movement between the skin and some rough surface in contact with it.
  • They show uneven, longitudinal parallel lines (grooves or furrows) with the epithelium heaped up at the endsof these lines, which indicate the direction in which the force was applied.
  • Usually, the skin is uniformly denuded at the start or may be serrated.
  • The epidermis is scraped away, destroyed, or detached.
  • A glancing abrasion caused by a tangential force is known as 'brush abrasion'or 'grazes' or 'brush burn.' It is commonly seen when a body is dragged over a rough surface, such as a road. This scrapes linear furrows across the skin. The epidermal tags raised by the impact tend to pile up at the distal end.

Option A: Fishtailing is the shape of the stab wound caused by a single-edged weapon.

Option C: Tailing of the wound indicates the direction of injury in incised wounds.

Option D: Crushed hair follicles are seen at the edge of the wound in a laceration.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of cushing's triad?
questions.solution:
• Uncontrolled increases in ICP result in cerebral herniation.
  • Typically, herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe over the tentorium results in pupil abnormalities, usually occurring first on the side of any expanding haematoma.
  • Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum compresses medullary vasomotor and respiratory centres, classically producing Cushing's triad; hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration.
  • The patient is then said to be 'coning', and brainstem death will result without immediate intervention.

Wet weather flow: The amount of sewage flowing in a system in 24 hours in a rainy day.

questions.text: Mechanism of cyanide poisoning is by inhibiting:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of cyanide poisoning is by inhibiting Cytochrome oxidase

Action:

  • Cyanide inhibits the action of cytochrome oxidase, carbonic anhydrase and probably of other enzyme systems.
  • It blocks the final step of oxidative phosphorylation and prevents the formation of ATP and its use as energy source.
  • Cyanide acts by reducing the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood, and by combining with the ferric iron atom of intracellular cytochrome oxidase, preventing the uptake of oxygen for cellular respiration.
  • There is an interference with the intracellular oxidative processes in the tissues and it kills by creating histotoxic or cytotoxic anoxia, although the blood may contain a normal oxygen content.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. Laparoscopy reveals powder-burn lesions on the peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus, often leading to chronic pelvic pain, severe dysmenorrhea, and infertility. One of the classic findings on laparoscopy is the presence of powder-burn lesions, or dark brown-black lesions on the peritoneum, which represent old blood deposits from endometrial tissue.

Option Explanations:

  • B) Adenomyosis: Involves the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium of the uterus. It typically causes heavy menstrual bleeding and a uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus, but it is not associated with powder-burn lesions on laparoscopy.
  • C) Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): Typically presents with pelvic pain, fever, and abnormal discharge, but does not cause powder-burn lesions. It is an infection of the upper reproductive tract, often associated with tubal damage.
  • D) Uterine fibroids: Non-cancerous growths in the uterus that cause heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure but are not associated with powder-burn lesions or the type of pelvic pain described here.

questions.text: When does the basi-occiput fuses with basi-sphenoid?
questions.solution:
• The spheno-occipital suturefuses by about 18-20 years in females and by about 20-22 years in males.
  • The timing of cranial suture closure was one of the first techniques used to estimate the age of adult individuals
  • The spheno-occipital suture on the skull base is particularly useful for aging young adults. The other cranial sutures show more variation in the timing of closure.

Sutures fuse 5-10 years earlier in the endocranial surface than on the ectocranial surface, and this must also be taken into account when using this method. Overall, this method of age determination is less reliable.

Age of fusion (in years) of skull sutures.

questions.text: 40 years old Man had past history of exercise induced muscle cramps which was somewhat relieved by taking glucose rich drink. He also had noticed about red brown color of urine after prolonged exercise and extreme weakness in legs. Identify the clinical condition.
questions.solution:
A 40 years old man is suffering from myophosphorylase (muscle glycogen phosphorylase) Deficiency thereby inability to break down muscle glycogen to glucose 6 phosphate. Red colored urine may be due to Myoglobinuria.

  • ↑ glycogen in muscle, but muscle cannot break it down -> painful muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (red urine) with strenuous exercise, and arrhythmia from electrolyte abnormalities.
  • Second-wind phenomenon noted during exercise due to ↑ muscular blood flow.
  • Characterized by a flat venous lactate curve with normal rise in ammonia levels during exercise

choices.text: Implied term of contract between doctor and patient

questions.text: Professional secrecy is
questions.solution:
• Professional secrecy is an implied term of contract between the doctor and his patient.
  • The doctor is obliged to keep secret, all that he comes to know concerning the patient in the course of his professional work.
  • Its disclosure would be a failure of trust and confidence.
  • The patient can sue the doctor for damages if the disclosure is voluntary, has resulted in harm to the patient and is not in the interest of the public.

questions.text: A pregnant lady attended an antenatal clinic with a history of developmental delay, presence cataract, history of Milk intolerance in her earlier child. During her previous pregnancy, quadriple testing for screening was normal. Clinician is suspecting Metabolic Disorder. Investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis for fetus is
questions.solution:
This is case of Classical Galactosemia. In this disorder Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyl transferase deficiency.Prenatal diagnosis is possible with Chorionic Villus sampling.

Classic galactosemia

  • Enzyme defect : Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase(autosomal recessive).

Damage caused by accumulation of toxic substances (eg, galacitol).

Symptoms start when infant is fed formula or breast milk :

  • failure to thrive
  • jaundice
  • hepatomegaly,
  • infantile cataracts (galacitol deposition in eye lens),
  • intellectual disability.
  • Can predispose neonates to E coli sepsis.

Treatment : Exclude galactose and lactose (galactose + glucose) from diet.

Option A) 4 - D Sonography may be supportive but not the choice for confirming the diagnosis during intrauterine life .

Option B) AFP & B HCG levels are tumor markers & can help for diagnosis of various developmental defects of fetus.

Option C) Amniotic Fluid Analysis can be used for some metabolic conditions but CVS is more direct and sensitive test for Detection of GALT deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle get inserted on marked arrow bone ?
questions.solution:
The marked arrow bone is the navicular bone.

Option wise explanation :

Option A: Tibialis anterior : It is inserted on the inferomedial surface of medial cuneiform and adjoining part of base of first metatarsal bone.

Option B: Tibialis Posterior : It is inserted on tuberosity of navicular bone and other tarsal bones except talus. Insertion is extended into 2nd , 3rd and 4th metatarsal bones.

Option C: Flexor hallucis longus : It is inserted on plantar surface of the base of distal phalanx of big toe.

Option D: Peroneus tertius : It is inserted over the medial part of the dorsal surface of base of 5th metatarsal bone.

questions.text: A doctor is
questions.solution:
• Common witness is also known as ordinary witness.
  • A doctor is both common as well as expert witness. For example, when a doctor is mentioning about the dimensions and situation of a wound, he acts as common witness and when he mentions about the type of the wound, causative object etc., he acts as expert witness.
  • The Indian Medical Council Act 1956 in section 15 (2) (C) states that, no person other than a medical practitioner enrolled on a state medical register shall be entitled to give evidence at any inquest or in any court of law as an expert under Sec. 39 BSA on any matter relating to medicine.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is pregnant with twins conceived via in vitro fertilization (IVF). Ultrasound at 16 weeks shows monochorionic monoamniotic twins. Which of the following complications is specific to this condition?
questions.solution:
Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both the same chorion and amniotic sac, meaning they are in the same sac without a dividing membrane. This condition has specific risks, the most important of which is cord entanglement. Because both twins share the same amniotic sac, their umbilical cords can become entangled, leading to compromised blood flow and a high risk of fetal complications, including death.

Option Explanations:

  • A) Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): While TTTS is a complication specific to monochorionic twins (those sharing a placenta), it typically occurs in monochorionic diamniotic twins (with separate amniotic sacs) rather than monoamniotic twins.
  • C) Fetal growth restriction: This can occur in any type of twin pregnancy but is not specific to monochorionic monoamniotic twins.
  • D) Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM): A common complication in multiple pregnancies, but not specific to monochorionic monoamniotic twins.

questions.text: Strychnine acts by inhibiting:
questions.solution:
• Strychnine competitively blocks ventral horn motor neuron postganglionic receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem and prevents the effects of glycine (the presumed inhibitory transmitter).
  • Widespread inhibition in the spinal cord results in 'release' excitation.
  • The action is particularly noted in the anterior horn cells.
  • It stimulates the cerebral cortex.
  • GABA, the neurotransmitter for presynaptic inhibitory neurons is not affected.

questions.text: Identify this finding in cardiotocography CTG:
questions.solution:
A)Early Deceleration: Gradual decrease in FHR before contraction peak, returning to baseline by end. Cause: Head compression. Significance: Normal, no fetal distress.


Other options:

B)Late Deceleration: Gradual decrease in FHR after contraction peak, returning to baseline after contraction. Cause: Uteroplacental insufficiency. Significance: Abnormal, indicates fetal distress.

C)Variable Deceleration: Abrupt decrease in FHR with varying onset and duration. Cause: Umbilical cord compression. Significance: Can be normal or abnormal, depending on severity.

D)Sinusoidal Pattern: Smooth, wave-like FHR pattern. Cause: Severe fetal hypoxia or anemia. Significance: Abnormal, indicates severe fetal compromise.

questions.text: All are true of OPC poisoning, except:

questions.text: Anterior and posterior neuropore closes respectively as follow
questions.solution:
Neurulation:

  • The process of neural tube formation is termed as neurulation.
  • The fusion of neural folds begins in the middle and it simultaneously proceeds in the cephalic and caudal directions.
  • The fusion at cranial and caudal ends of neural tube is delayed forming small openings called anterior and posterior neuropore.
  • The neural tube and overlying amniotic cavity, therefore remains temporarily in open communication with each other through these pores.
  • The anterior neuropore closes earlier, in the middle of 4th week at 18-20 somite stage (25th day) and the posterior neuropore closes later at the end of 4th week at about 25 somite stage (28th day).
  • By the time the neural tube is completely closed, it is divided into an enlarged cranial part and an elongated caudal part, which later on gives rise to brain and spinal cord, respectively.

Option wise explanation:

Option A, C and D are incorrect for closing of neuropore.

Option B: Anterior neuropore close on day 25 and posterior neuropore close on day 28.
